title: Assembly language
summary: In computer programming,  assembly language (or assembler language),[1] sometimes abbreviated asm, is any low-level programming language in which there is a very strong correspondence between the instructions in the language and the architecture's machine code instructions.[2] Assembly language usually has one statement per machine instruction (1:1), but  constants, comments, assembler directives,[3] symbolic labels of, e.g., memory locations, registers, and macros[4][1] are generally also supported.
